definition: to describe sth as/an analogy/a simile/a metaphor/an allegory

sentences.chinese: 无遮盖的人体画像，有时具有讽喻意义。

sentences.english: He believes that Yuanhe style should include allegory poem by Yuan Zhen and Bai Juyi.
sentences.chinese: 张文认为“元和体”应包括元白讽喻诗。

sentences.english: The undraped human figure, sometimes allegorical.
sentences.chinese: 无覆盖的人体画像，有时具有讽喻意义。

sentences.english: The composite animal in Book IX is an allegory of the parts of the soul.
sentences.chinese: 第四卷谈到的混合动物则是心灵部分的一种讽喻。

sentences.english: The book is a kind of allegory of Latin American history.
sentences.chinese: 这本书是对拉丁美洲历史的一种讽喻。

sentences.english: Let me share with you a beautiful allegory.
sentences.chinese: 让我与您分享一个美好的讽喻。

sentences.english: A depiction of natural land forms, sometimes allegorical.
sentences.chinese: 以自然风景为主题，有时含有讽喻意义的作品。

definition: to use the past to disparage the present (idiom)
to borrow the past as a model for the present
variant of 諷喻|讽喻[feng3 yu4]
(literary) to remonstrate with one's superior tactfully
to critique/to voice concerns about/ancient form of acupuncture using sharp stones as needles
falsification in writing/misrepresentation in written history/deliberate digression
to compare oneself/to view oneself as
to use sth as a metaphor
